newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish bonds set for more falls after CPI data.
newsitem.headline: Danish bonds set for more falls after CPI data.

text.p: Danish bond prices slipped on Wednesday on disappointing CPI data after early rises on U.S. Fed Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's positive testimony, with further modest falls in quiet trade foreseen by dealers.

"Greenspan's speech sparked solid early gains but then market disappointment in the latest Danish and German inflation data dented optimism. Profit-taking also contributed to the decline. Falls will go on until the close," one dealer said.
The benchmark eight percent state bond due 2006 was down 0.28 point from the opening at 114.36, with yield at 5.83 percent at 1015 GMT.

The seven percent 2007 bond, due to become benchmark September 1, fell 0.31 point to 107.23, yielding 6.03 percent. Turnover in the 2006 and 2007 bonds was 2.2 billion and just under one billion crowns respectively.

The 2006's September future rose 0.41 point to 114.00 with 277 contracts traded. The six percent mortgage bond due 2026 gained 0.25 point to 92.80. The crown traded at a virtually static 3.8067 per mark at 1045 GMT. The 2007's 10-year yield gap with Germany was unchanged at 52 basis points.
The Central Bank sold a small amount of short-term state bonds.
